text: was a after Anna and before Ten'en. This period started in March 970 and ended in March 973.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Tenroku" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 961. The reigning emperors were and .Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, pp. 144-145; Brown, Delmer et al. (1979). Gukanshō, pp. 299-300; Varley, H. Paul. (1980). Jinnō Shōtōki, pp. 191-192. ==Events of the Tenroku era== * 970 (Tenroku 1, 1st month): became Minister of the Left (sadaijin); and became Minister of the Right (udaijin) in the Imperial court hierarchy.Titsingh, p. 144. * 970 (Tenroku 1, 5th month): died at the age of 71; and the Koretada took his place as chief advisor to the emperor. * 970 (Tenroku 1, 10th month): died at age 79. He had held the office of sadaijin. * 971 (Tenroku 2, 3rd month): For the first time, a festival (matsuri) in honor of the kami of Iwashimizu Shrine was celebrated. * 971 (Tenroku 2, in the 11th month): Koretada was created Prime Minister (daijō- daijin); was made sadaijin; and was named udaijin.Titsingh, pp. 144-145. * 4 April 972 (Tenroku 3, 5th day of the 3rd month): Koretada organized ceremonies which confirmed Emperor En'yū's role as monarch .Titsingh, p. 145. * 972 (Tenroku 3, 11th month): Koretada died at age 49. ==Related pages == * Heian period ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Tenroku 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 970 971 972 973 Preceded by: Anna Era or nengō: Tenroku Succeeded by: Ten'en Category:Japanese eras Category:10th-century establishments in Japan Category:10th-century disestablishments in Japan Category:970s establishments Category:970s disestablishments
title: Tenroku
